56F989079F614CD6A3D34A74794CF046.description:
Calculate probabilities of compound events using organized
lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation. For example, Calculate the
probability of â€œrolling double sixes.â€ Use a simulation to approximate the
answer to the question. For example, if 40% of blood donors have type A
blood, what is the probability that it will take at least 4 blood donors to
find one with type A blood?

6239B379C9A94DFD83875887FD174319.description:
Calculate probabilities of simple events under an assumption of
equal probability for all outcomes. For example, suppose that one
student in seventh grade will be chosen to speak at a school assembly.
On the assumption that every student is equally likely to be chosen,
calculate the probability that the youngest seventh grader will be chosen
and the probability that a member of Homeroom 701 will be chosen.
Calculate the probability of a spinner landing on a certain color, assuming
that all of the colors are equally likely outcomes.

E032AED85231423CBE6E571B90DF2DDB.description:
Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting
data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run
relative frequency. Given the probability of a chance event, predict the
approximate relative frequency that will be observed, and collect data to
assess the agreement between the probability and the observed
frequency. For example, collect data to approximate the probability that a
tossed paper cup will land open-end down. Your friend calculated that
the probability of â€œrolling double sixesâ€ with a pair of number cubes is 1
6
(which is the wrong answer) collect data to see how well this probability
agrees with the observation frequency.Â

0BDC9E7BDE4C4AAB9C0BF0A9FBE74721.description:
Describe the probability of a chance event as a number
between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. (for
example, larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0
indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1
2 indicates an event that
is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely
event).

94833D45481540BC96877412B989F768.description:
Use measures of center (for example, mode, median, mean)
and measures of variability (for example, range, interquartile range,
mean absolute deviation) for numerical data from random samples to
draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For
example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade
science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourthgrade science book.

40F4B3D721604CC9A7672B9B1872A5D1.description:
Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical
data distributions with similar variability, measuring the difference
between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of
variability. For example, the mean height of players on the basketball
team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer
team, about twice the variability (mean absolute deviation) on either
team; on a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of
heights is noticeable.

8D933D18EFB44EA29F4E7B739991F5FF.description: Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.Â

C50E1D33EA2B41BBAF70CEAC629FBF8B.description:
Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a
population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple
samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation
in estimates or predictions. For example, estimate the mean word length
in a book by randomly sampling words from the book; predict the winner
of a school election based on randomly sampled survey data and
observe the variation in predictions across multiple surveys.Â Â

10B0DE64A14D43148E27E097A1A2F1F4.description:
Describe how statistics can be used to gain information about a
population by examining a sample of the population, recognizing that
generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the
sample is representative of that population. Explain that random
sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid
inferences.

8E139EBDAA5D448496C9F8CC42948C32.description: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.

39B8260986AD4C30BA2D7D9C67F45979.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area,
volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects
composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.Â

38F5D264EB7F46C59FF9EC054A21DE45.description:
Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and
adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple
equations for an unknown angle in a figure.Â

D0F16561199B481599F1B4DE09C0BA51.description:
Choose the formula needed and use it to solve problems
involving the area and circumference of a circle. For example, a 15.1 in
long wire is bent into the shape of a circle to make a wreath with 2.9 in
left over. To the nearest 0.1 in, what is the diameter of the circle?

549D04DB665C454AB3A1B02FAE53AB99.description:
Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface
area, and volume.

3E10CF3E709E4AB8A3F34C2E1C61E54C.description:
Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing
three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms
and right rectangular pyramids.

4DFEBD41F25A4630B2EDB7A27E0DF907.description:
Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology)
geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles
from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions
determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.

2AB110C5B56348F79B86C0A278B713F7.description:
Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures,
including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and
reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.

C8F769E408D3479CB3C2EE487D5468E5.description:
Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures and describe the relationships
between them.

DAEB84C2D4714FCF97DB1BC133D7603D.description:
Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ‘ğ‘ >
ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ or ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ‘ğ‘ < ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ, where ğ‘ğ‘, ğ‘ğ‘, and ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ are specific rational numbers.
Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the
context of the problem. For example, as a salesperson, you are
paid $50 per week plus $3 per sale. This week you want your
pay to be at least $100. Write an inequality for the number of
sales you need to make and describe the solutions. ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ‘ğ‘ > ï¿½

7A11B7D029AE42DEAB2BBD464916D534.description:
Solve word problems leading to equations of the form ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ‘ğ‘ = ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ
and ğ‘ğ‘(ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ + ğ‘ğ‘) = ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ, where ğ‘ğ‘, ğ‘ğ‘, and ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ are specific rational
numbers. Solve equations of these forms fluently. Compare an
algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution, identifying the
sequence of the operations used in each approach. For example,
the perimeter of a rectangle is 54 cm. Its length is 6 cm. What is
its width?

4FAFACF79C3D444E8BC893E10AF23D98.description:
Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or
mathematical problem and construct simple equations and inequalities to
solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

5241B818FDC448F8B487B3E6D086D502.description:
Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed
with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers,
fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of
operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms
as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental
computation and estimation strategies. For example, If someone making
$25 an hour gets a 10% raise, that is an additional 1
10 of their salary an
hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel
bar 9 3
4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1
2 inches wide, you
will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate
can be used as a check on the exact computation.Â

D0D7CB63535244E2A17B1DDC3DAD0121.description:
Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions
and equations.

B4D1EBBF1FED42FFBC494A90CE4849D0.description:
Describe how rewriting an expression in different forms in a
problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities
in it are related. For example, ğ‘ğ‘ + 0.05ğ‘ğ‘ = 1.05ğ‘ğ‘ means that "increase
by 5%" is the same as "multiply by 1.05."Â

01DA1646755C4FB893B117F3878D14C0.description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract,
factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.Â

D353ABE9F578437F946855F6613D2F1A.description: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

4BEFA8E237D547B6AB2086C2841BA8EA.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the
four operations with rational numbers. Computations with rational
numbers extend the rules for manipulating fractions to complex
fractions, a fraction within a fraction.Â

A601197E5E624799AA753D0EE95821A7.description:
Convert a rational number to a decimal; know that the decimal
form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually
repeats.

9C58417D6FDA4DD39F3B6E5F0AADBFB9.description:
Use properties of operations, particularly the distributive
property, leading to generalizations for quotients of integers
(provided that the divisor is not zero). If ğ‘ğ‘ and ğ‘ğ‘ are integers,
then âˆ’ ï¿½ğ‘ğ‘
ğ‘ğ‘
ï¿½ = (âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘)
ğ‘ğ‘ = ğ‘ğ‘
(âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘)
. Interpret quotients of rational
numbers by describing real-world contexts.

C86E87E0B1E3499F92E2E188F1F7ABB9.description:
Use properties of operations, particularly the distributive
property, leading to generalizations for products such as
(âˆ’1)(âˆ’1) = 1 for multiplying signed numbers. Interpret
products of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

EA3BA2C23DF34F6FABB35B23CD2E97AC.description:
Apply and extend earlier understandings of multiplication and
division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.Â

D023F6546A104018AECBE92C3597FC73.description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and
subtract rational numbers.

28E6D2DA79D7430AAD606A8B5DD18874.description:
Use a model to describe subtraction of rational numbers as
adding the additive inverse, ğ‘ğ‘ âˆ’ ğ‘ğ‘ = ğ‘ğ‘ + (âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘). Show that the
distance between two rational numbers on the number line is
the absolute value of their difference and apply this principle in
real-world contexts.

A994314AA1F54BD3BCC2A452CCB6D309.description:
Use a model to describe ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ‘ğ‘ as a number located a distance
|ğ‘ğ‘| from ğ‘ğ‘, in the positive or negative direction depending on
whether ğ‘ğ‘ is positive or negative. Show that a number and its
opposite have a sum of 0 (are additive inverses). Interpret
sums of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

075D15FFE68E4A80A4EC2BE4B175CAC6.description:
Describe situations in which opposite quantities combine to
make 0. For example, a hydrogen atom has 0 charge because
its two constituents are oppositely charged.Â Â

926FEDDEEC3C46A8BEF609DB913A7235.description:
Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and
subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition
and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

9EA49975B1F34AE88D51B7FA2511CA49.description:
Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract,
multiply, and divide rational numbers.

7E57730B89AC4E68B1B2A37F100DB9AF.description:
Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and
percent problems. For example: simple interest, tax, markups and
markdowns, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and
decrease, percent error.

2AB2C2BDAEA242579BB5B9C907337401.description:
Explain what a point (ğ‘¥ğ‘¥, ğ‘¦ğ‘¦) on the graph of a proportional
relationship means in terms of the situation, with special
attention to the points (0,0) and (1, ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ) where ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ is the unit rate.Â

D2918F63FBC6434990E633D9F4C62699.description:
Represent proportional relationships by equations. For
example, if total cost t is proportional to the number n of items
bought at a constant price p, the relationship between the total
cost and the number of items can be expressed as ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ = ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘.

C6FEB435118E4C24A279BE7CE348F268.description:
Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables,
graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of
proportional relationships.

42F6C3CD14F146EF91D20FE1990B5EA8.description:
Decide whether two quantities are in a proportional
relationship. For example, by testing for equivalent ratios in a
table or graphing on a coordinate plane and observing whether
the graph is a straight line through the origin.

4B0F46A738004AD3ADC9943A2D5C1A37.description:
Recognize and represent proportional relationships between
quantities.Â

A52919F0265F4BFFAF7EF9B658A41636.description:
Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions,
including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like
or different units. For example, if a person walks 1
2 mile in each 1
4 hour,
compute the unit rate as the complex fraction
1
2
1
4
miles per hour,
equivalently 2 miles per hour. Give a reason it is a better value to buy a
supply of an item at a cost of $22.50 for ten pounds than at a cost of
$1.50 for 1
2 pound.

A40C3EAD88BA42138F07D8A55E5354F9.description:
Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical
problems.Â
